text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

RANJAY GULATI: The
3rd T is for teamwork.

Pretty much every
single coach I talked
to talked about team culture.

How do you create
this team culture

that, in turn, plays a huge
role in how well you can perform
as a team, as a collective?

And a lot of it has to do
with the tone the coach sets,

setting expectations,
creating clearly defined

criteria of what is
acceptable and not acceptable.

So if you look at Nick
Saban and Alabama,

it's very clearly
defined expectations

of performance and behavior
at practice, in the game,
and outside.

So sometimes punishing
players is as much

of a signal and
affirmation of the culture
as rewarding players.

Another lever people use
is the slogan for the team.

Here in New England, Bill
Belichick's team slogan
is do your job.

Do your job, meaning I'm
holding you responsible.

If you do your job, everybody
else is doing their job.

But it also means stay in your
lane and only do your job,
not anybody else's job.

And by the way, if you don't
do your job, you're out.

So there are many ways
to interpret that.

And some may say positive,
some may not like it.

And there's a self-selection
that happens there.
Contrast that with Pete Carroll.

So Pete Carroll, the Seattle
Seahawks coach, their team
slogan is I'm in.

And that has different
connotations.
It connotes a team.
It connotes commitment.
It connotes personal connection.

It is going to elicit a
different kind of reaction.

It's also going to attract
a different kind of person.

Who wants to work
in a "do your job?"

Who wants to work
in an "I'm in?"

You have to ask yourself,
what kind of organization
do I want to lead?

One of the other
elements of culture

is to create this kind
of egalitarian mindset

that we are all in this
team, and no one is special.

So if you look at
Nick Saban, he has

a saying about structured
accountability.

Everyone has the same rules
applied to them equally.
No one is guaranteed playtime.

No matter who you are, no matter
how special you think you are,
you're not guaranteed playtime.

You got to earn the
right to play every game.

Some of the challenges
these coaches

face when they
have star players.

Sir Alex Ferguson
with David Beckham.

In some cases, like Sir Alex
Ferguson, he let Beckham go.

He said, you know
what, you may be

the best player in
the world, but I
don't want you on my team.

Or you have Phil Jackson
working with Kobe saying,

if you really want to be the
leader of this team, which

I think you do, you got to
change the way you show up.

So how do these
coaches recognize

that star talent may at
some time, at some moment
get too big for themselves?

And how do you keep everybody
in check and measured?
That's part of the culture.

If you look at some surveys of
business leaders, close to 90%

say culture is critical to
the success of our business.

And then asked to what
degree is your culture where

it should be, 16% say
it's where it should be.

It's one of those things
that we systematically

talk about, say it's important,
and then go on to neglect it.

Culture is also a
magnet for talent,

the self-selection
that happens when
you have a kind of culture.

If you want to be a
high-performance organization

attracting
high-performance talent,

you need a culture that draws
them to want to come there.

And there's data showing
that more than 80%

of talented people choose to
join a company for the culture

and leave companies
for the culture.

There's now research showing
that how people perform at work

depends on how connected they
feel to what they're doing.

If my work is a job, the maximum
I'm going to get out of it
is being satisfied in my job.
It's called job satisfaction.

That leads to a certain
level of productivity.

If I'm engaged,
engaged comes when

you feel you have
responsibility, autonomy.

That leads to a higher
level of productivity.

You can go to the next
level called inspired.

And in an article that came
out in Harvard Business

Review in 2015, they
showed inspired workers

are more than twice as
productive as satisfied
workers.

We have to ask
ourselves, is there

something we can do to put
our culture to work in a way
that elicits inspired work?

And if you look at
some of these teams,

you can start by saying
some players do it

for themselves because if I play
well, my record gets better.
I'm more marketable.
I can make more money.

Some will say I do
it for the team.

I feel responsible and
committed to the team.

I really want to
do it for the team.

And others say I do it because
this is a calling to me.
I do it for my coach.
I do it for glory.

I do it for something
bigger than myself.

What, as a coach or a
leader, are you tapping into?

I think some of the
greatest coaches

are able to go from job
to engaged to inspired.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
